article.headline: Utah 71, Whitworth 49
article.story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- With just one senior healthy enough to play and the only other one on the roster nursing an ailing back, Utah coach Rick Majerus knows Utah's non-conference record could have been much worse. The Utes (12-3) closed their non-conference schedule Wednesday night with a 71-49 win against Division III Whitworth, extending their winning streak to six straight and staying unbeaten at home. "I'm proud that the guys hustle and try hard," Majerus said. "Every day they grind it out and every day they show a degree of resiliency. That's just the way it is. They're young." The Utes played their second straight game without center Tim Frost, who is out indefinitely with a bad back and has missed three of the last four games with a bad back. Frost and shooting guard Nick Jacobson, who had seven points Wednesday, are Utah's only seniors. Freshman Andrew Bogut moved over from forward to Frost's spot and scored 18 points and pulled down 15 rebounds, two nights after being held scoreless for the first time in his college career. The 6-foot-10 Australian got his seventh double-double of the season. "You forget what he is. He's a freshman. He's four years out of eighth grade in a foreign country," Majerus said. "Bogut's a young kid." The Utes, who were the Mountain West Conference regular-season co-champions last season, were 26-for-52 from the field and outrebounded Whitworth 40-22. Utah opens MWC play at UNLV on Monday. "It was a good win, but it could have been better," said Richard Chaney, who had 14 points for the Utes. "Our record is pretty good and I'm pretty excited about that coming into conference. We've just got to keep it up," Whitworth (7-2) hadn't lost since the season opener and scared Utah in a six-point loss two years before in the Huntsman Center, but on Wednesday was no match for the bigger Utes after a quick start. The Pirates were just 18-for-54 (33 percent) from the field and leading scorer Bryan Depew finished with just 18 points, five fewer than his average. Depew, a 58 percent shooter, was just 6-for-24 Monday. "We knew coming in here we had to be a great shooting team tonight. The ball didn't fall in the hoop," Depew said. "But it was great. We did a lot of good things that will carry over to our league play." The Pirates made their first four 3-pointers and led 16-13 before Josh Olsen tied it with a 3. Bryant Markson followed with a two-handed dunk and Chris Jackson made a layup as the Utes used a 9-0 run to pull away. Chaney made two 3s later in the half as he scored eight straight for Utah, which led 38-30 at halftime after hitting 15 of 26 field goals, including 4-for-8 3-pointers. Utah opened the second half with another 8-0 run, then minutes later Chaney, who had a career-high 27 points Monday in a win over Pepperdine, increased the lead to 60-40 with a steal and two-handed dunk. The Utes coasted the rest of the way to improve to 9-0 at home.
